segments.en: Linked Discourses 4
2. Rule
13. A Splinter
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati maddakucchismiṃ migadāye.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Maddakucchi deer park.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khato hoti,
segments.en: Now at that time the Buddha’s foot had been cut by a splinter.

segments.pli: bhusā sudaṃ bhagavato vedanā vattanti sārīrikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā.
segments.en: The Buddha was stricken by harrowing pains; physical feelings that were painful, sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, and disagreeable.

segments.pli: Tā sudaṃ bhagavā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno.
segments.en: But he endured with mindfulness and situational awareness, without worrying.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapetvā dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno.
segments.en: And then he spread out his outer robe folded in four and laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:
“Are you feeble that you lie down? Or are you drunk on poetry?

segments.pli: Atthā nu te sampacurā na santi;
segments.en: Don’t you have all that you need?
Alone in a secluded lodging,
why this sleeping, sleepyhead?”
“I’m not feeble that I lie down, nor am I drunk on poetry.
Having reached the goal, I’m rid of sorrow.
Alone in a secluded lodging,
I lie down full of compassion for all living creatures.
Even those with a dart stuck in the breast,
piercing the heart again and again,
are able to get some sleep.
So why not I, whose dart is drawn out?

segments.pli: Jaggaṃ na saṅke napi bhemi sottuṃ,
segments.en: I don’t lie awake tense, nor do I fear to sleep.
The days and nights don’t disturb me,
as I see no decline for myself in the world.
That’s why I lie down full of compassion for all living creatures.”

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
segments.en: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha rests after being struck by stone splinters, and Māra criticizes him for being lazy.
